Countdown Tip # 5 -- Review the arrival procedures and discuss these with your child so they know what to expect when they return to campus. What is noticeably different this year is that parents are not allowed to walk their children inside of the building, so if your child is used to this, a discussion beforehand will help them anticipate what drop-off will actually look like.

Arrival
Students may not arrive earlier than 7 am at the elementary schools or 8:15 am at secondary schools. Any students dropped off before the building is open will not be allowed inside the building.

Separate entrances will be utilized for car riders, bus riders, and walkers.

All staff will be utilized for duty to maintain a line of sight in hallways and distancing of hallway cohorts.

Sanitizer stations will be placed at each entrance and students will sanitize hands upon entry.

Parents will not be allowed to accompany students into the building. Students will go straight to the classroom upon arrival and will not wait in a centralized holding area.

10 days until on-campus learning begins for those who selected to have their children return (except for Lockhart Junior High School, which will transition back to campus October 19)! If you have not already, start having you child practice wearing a mask at home to prepare for wearing a mask throughout the school day.

The American Academy of Pediatrics has helpful information for parents about cloth face coverings for children during COVID-19, including:

Have your child practice wearing the face covering in small increments of time to help him get used to it.
Put a cloth face covering on a favorite stuffed animal.
Decorate the masks so that they are more personalized and fun.

What is the best way for a child to wear a face covering?

Have her wear it over her nose and mouth, and make sure that it fits snugly against the sides of her face.
Show her how to take the mask off by pulling on the ear loops or ties.
Have her wash her hands before and after handling the mask.
Teach children not to touch or share their mask.

Together, we will work to keep each other safe! #LoveMyLISD

Parents: Please log in to Skyward and review your contact information to ensure it is correct. If it is not correct, you are able to edit that information in Skyward.

We're able to see which calls went to voicemail, which were answered in live calls, which emails were received, which bounced back ,and which emails were blocked. We can investigate more deeply and see what can be done to make sure you are receiving messages.

April Is School Library Month, and in LISD, we are fortunate to have a dedicated team of school librarians who go above and beyond for the students and staff at our schools. In this digital age, librarians not only manage physical collections of books and media resources, they also provide technological support, education resources and support, and prepare students for digital citizenship. In today's circumstances with physical school closures, librarians continue to provide valuable support with web and technical support for school distance learning webpages, doing virtual read alouds, sharing virtual field trips online, and providing distance support to teachers as they develop lessons for our Lions.

Our LISD school librarians are another reason to #LoveMyLISD!

The LISD Board of Trustees honored Chi Rocha for volunteering to serve as the tournament director for the FIRST LEGO League Lockhart Qualifier held in January 25.

The tournament was the first in district history, and it required the leadership of someone visionary, detail-oriented, and relentlessly focused on excellence.

This person not only coached teams to prepare for the event, she also coordinated an army of hundreds of volunteers to properly support this event while serving as the liaison with the FIRST Lego League tournament staff.

She will be quick to say she couldn’t have done it with the help of so many, but the fact is that she had the courage and desire to lead this extraordinary event as tournament director--on top of being a teacher, a coach, a mother, and all the other hats she wears.

For this reason, she was honored tonight, grateful for her stepping forward and making it possible to put Lockhart on the map for these STEM competitions.

Thank you, Chi Rocha, for helping to build a legacy of excellence!

#LoveMyLISD

Justin Fink of Visionary Fiber Technologies has been instrumental in the planning of our CTE STEM pathways for our Lions. Since joining the STEM advisory board in November, Mr. Fink has given his professional insight on the skills employers are looking for in their future employees. He has helped us develop a plan to ensure our students are not only equipped with those skills, but that they are highly marketable in such a competitive field.

Although new to Lockhart, he is invested in enriching our community and growing our students. Not only is he an active member of our STEM advisory board, he has also leant his insight to our district CTE advisory board, as well as volunteering to judge at our recent FIRST Lego League qualifier. Mr. Fink has truly embodied what it means to be a community partner and our students are at an advantage because of his continued involvement.

We are grateful for partners like Justin Fink for being personally invested in helping us prepare our students for success. #CTEMonth #LISDCTE #LoveMyLISD

Congratulations to our Literary Lions and Legendary Lions who competed at the Central Texas Battle of the Books this morning!

Central Texas Battle of the Books is an academic quiz game based on the 2019 Texas Lone Star Reading List. The Central Texas Battle of the Books was hosted by librarians, Keitha Hernandez (Lockhart Junior High School), Elizabeth Switek (Austin Discovery School), and Monica Cantu (Bertha Sadler Means Young Women's Leadership Academy, Austin ISD) at Region 13 Education Service Center. A total of 17 teams competed this year.

This year the 1st Place winners of the competition and of the poster contest are The Literary Lions. This team consists of Annabelle Peterson, Cole Frey, Lilly Gomillion, Laney Winton, Katelynn Shinkle and Thomas Utzinger.

Our second team, The Literary Legends, placed 4th in the competition and 3rd in the poster contest. This team consists of Jimmy Hinojosa, Jenna Hurt, Emma Bingham, Chloe Bingham, Dionie Mathurin, and Michael Salinas.

#LoveMyLISD

Yesterday, both the JV and Varsity winter guard teams competed at a competition at Georgetown High School and earned 1st place in their divisions of competition!

The Varsity team received a promotion to the next highest level of classification Scholastic AA to Scholastic A after their performance from the last competition, where they received second place. Even in competing in a higher division, they still secured first place!

Congratulations! #LoveMyLISD

February is Career and Technical Education (CTE) Month, and in Lockhart ISD, we value the education and preparation that our CTE coursework provides our Lions to be future-ready in a number of industries.

We are grateful to have community partners, like Hometown Cinemas, that invest directly in our Lions by enriching CTE instruction with real-world insight and applicability. Hometown Cinemas Director of Operations Keith Hester spent time students in the Lockhart High School Practicum of Audio & Visual class yesterday.

Mr. Hester touched on many topics including his background in his work in the movie industry, suggestions on how to better frame shots, how to have optimal lighting, and how to make theater-ready sound. We are grateful to Mr. Hester for his direct involvement with our students to ensure they are prepared for the workforce with real-world knowledge.

#CTEisWorldClass
#LoveMyLISD
